title: Simple – Boxing Stance & Linear Movement
subtitle: Master the boxing stance and the most basic movement fundamentals. Learn how to move in any direction while staying balanced and ready.

steps.text: Stand with your left foot forward and right foot back, feet just over shoulder-width apart. Front foot points to 12:30, rear to 2:30. Southpaws mirror this.
Shift your weight over your rear leg, bend your knees, and raise your rear heel. Stay light and ready, without leaning forward.
Tuck your elbows in. Rear hand floats in front of your face, front hand at shoulder level. Chin tucked, shoulders slightly rounded.
Front view: your body is turned inward to present a smaller target. Side view: upright posture, no leaning forward.
To move forward: push from your rear glute, step forward with lead foot, then rear foot follows the same distance.
To move backward: push from your front foot toe, step back with rear foot, then bring front foot back to stance.
To move right: push from lead foot, step right with rear foot first, then front foot follows. Lead glute fires first.
To move left: push from rear foot, step left with lead foot first, then rear foot follows to return to stance.

takeaways: Balance and structure are key — stay relaxed, knees bent, and weight on the balls of your feet.
Small, deliberate steps help maintain your stance and protection.
Footwork begins from the glutes — rear glute moves you forward, lead glute controls lateral steps.

title: Circling
subtitle: Move around your opponent, not just toward them. A mobile target is harder to hit.

steps.text: To circle left: step diagonally with your rear foot, then return to stance with your lead foot. Repeat smoothly.
To circle right: step diagonally with your lead foot, then return to stance with your rear foot. Pivot slightly on the lead foot.

takeaways: Circling keeps you balanced, mobile, and lets you create angles.
Step diagonally — rear foot first when circling left, lead foot first when circling right.
Use a slight pivot on your lead foot to stay aligned with your opponent.

title: Pivoting
subtitle: Shift your angle, stay in control. Use pivots to evade or attack from a better position.

steps.text: To pivot left: place about 60% of your weight on the lead foot and rotate on the ball of the foot, swinging your rear foot around.
To pivot right: step your rear foot out wide while pivoting your lead foot. Always finish in stance.

takeaways: Pivoting creates offensive and defensive angles while keeping you balanced.
To pivot left, rotate on your lead foot while swinging your rear foot into position.
To pivot right, step your rear foot out and pivot on the lead foot, returning to front-toe–rear-heel alignment.
